definitions.definition: The smallest administrative unit of land in feudal England, corresponding to the Anglo-Saxon tithing and the modern parish.
(now uncommon or literary) To wish, desire (something).
(nowadays rare) To wish or desire (that something happen); to intend (that).
(auxiliary) To choose to (do something); used to express intention but without any temporal connotations (+ bare infinitive), often in negation.
definitions.example: I’ve told him three times, but he won’t take his medicine.

definitions.definition: (auxiliary) Used to express the future tense, sometimes with some implication of volition when used in the first person. Compare shall.
(auxiliary) To be able to, to have the capacity to.
definitions.example: Unfortunately, only one of these gloves will actually fit over my hand.

definitions.definition: (auxiliary) Expressing a present tense with some conditional or subjective weakening: "will turn out to", "must by inference".
To instruct (that something be done) in one's will.
To try to make (something) happen by using one's will (intention).
definitions.example: All the fans were willing their team to win the game.

definitions.definition: To bequeath (something) to someone in one's will (legal document).
definitions.example: He willed his stamp collection to the local museum.
